metadata.title: Self-Inquiry Sequences
metadata.description: Structured exploration paths for investigating the nature of self and awareness

sequences.title: Who Am I? - Classical Self-Inquiry
sequences.description: The foundational inquiry into the nature of the self

steps.instruction: Sit comfortably and allow your body to settle. Take a few deep breaths.
Notice that you are aware right now. Simply recognize this obvious fact: awareness is present.
Ask yourself: Who am I? Don't answer with thoughts. Instead, turn attention back toward what is asking the question.
Notice thoughts arising: 'I am a person,' 'I am my body,' 'I am my mind.' Recognize these are thoughts appearing in awareness. You are what is aware of these thoughts.
Ask again: Who or what is aware of these thoughts? Let attention rest in the source of awareness itself.
If you find yourself thinking about awareness, gently return to being awareness. You cannot think your way to what you are. You can only recognize what you already are.
Rest as awareness. Let all experience come and go. Notice that awareness itself never comes or goes.
Gently return to the room. Notice that the awareness you recognized in stillness is the same awareness present in activity.

sequences.title: What Is Aware? - Tracing Experience to Its Source
sequences.description: Following the thread of awareness through different types of experience

steps.instruction: Notice a thought arising. Ask: What is aware of this thought?
Notice a feeling or emotion. Ask: What is aware of this feeling?
Notice a bodily sensation. Ask: What is aware of this sensation?
Notice a perception (sight or sound). Ask: What is aware of this perception?
Notice that the same awareness is aware of all these different experiences. This awareness is what you are.
Rest as this awareness. Let all experience come and go, recognized as appearances in awareness.

sequences.title: Investigating the Separate Self
sequences.description: Looking directly at the sense of being a separate person

steps.instruction: Notice the sense of being 'me'—a separate person located in the body. Just notice this sense without judgment.
Ask: Where is this 'me' located? Is it in the head? The chest? Somewhere else? Look carefully.
Ask: What is the shape, size, or color of this 'me'? Can these qualities be found?
Notice thoughts about 'me' arising: 'I am this,' 'I am that.' Recognize these are thoughts appearing in awareness, not what you are.
Ask: Can this separate 'me' actually be found? Or is it just a thought-feeling that comes and goes?
Notice what remains when the search for a separate self is abandoned. Simply awareness, present and obvious.

sequences.title: The Nature of Thought
sequences.description: Seeing thoughts as objects in awareness

steps.instruction: Notice a thought arising. Recognize it as an object appearing in awareness.
Ask: Who or what is aware of this thought? Notice the awareness that knows the thought.
Watch thoughts coming and going like clouds in the sky. Notice that awareness is not affected by thoughts.
Notice the space between thoughts. What is present in this space? Only awareness.
Ask: If I am not my thoughts, who am I? Rest in the awareness that knows all thoughts.

sequences.title: Am I the Body?
sequences.description: Investigating the relationship between awareness and the body

steps.instruction: Close your eyes and notice bodily sensations. Recognize these sensations as objects appearing in awareness.
Ask: What is aware of these sensations? Who or what knows the body?
Notice that the body is known through sensations. When sensations are not present (as in deep sleep), the body is not known. But awareness remains.
Ask: Am I the body, or am I what is aware of the body? If the body appears in awareness, how can I be limited to the body?
Notice thoughts arising: 'But I must be the body!' Recognize these are thoughts appearing in awareness, not direct experience.
Rest as awareness. Notice the body appears in you, as awareness. You do not appear in the body.

sequences.title: Am I Aware? - The Simplest Recognition
sequences.description: The most direct inquiry, returning immediately to presence

steps.instruction: Ask yourself: Am I aware? Notice the immediate recognition: Yes.
Don't think about it. Don't analyze. Simply notice the obvious fact: awareness is present.
Ask again: Am I aware? Notice there is no gap between the question and recognition. It is immediate.
This awareness that recognizes itself—this is what you are. Not a thought about awareness, but awareness itself.
Rest as awareness. Whenever attention wanders into thought or activity, gently ask: Am I aware? Return home.

sequences.title: Awareness in Daily Activity
sequences.description: Recognizing awareness while engaged in everyday tasks

steps.instruction: While doing a simple task (washing dishes, walking, eating), pause and ask: Am I aware?
Notice that awareness is present even during activity. You don't have to stop doing to be aware.
Continue the activity, but let attention rest in awareness rather than only in the activity.
Notice: activity appears in awareness. Awareness is not disturbed by activity.
Repeat this throughout the day with different activities. Let awareness become the background of all experience.

sequences.title: Where Is Happiness?
sequences.description: Investigating the source of happiness and peace

steps.instruction: Think of a time when you felt happy. Recall the experience as vividly as possible.
Ask: Did the happiness come from the object or situation? Or did it come from within?
Notice that when desire was fulfilled, seeking temporarily stopped. In that moment, what you are was revealed.
Ask: If happiness came from objects, why does it fade? Why must I keep seeking new objects?
Recognize: happiness is the nature of awareness itself. It is revealed when seeking ceases, not when an object is acquired.
Rest as awareness. Notice the quiet joy, the causeless peace that is always present as your nature.
Think of another person. Notice the sense that they are 'over there' and you are 'here.'
Ask: What is aware of the thought of this person? Your awareness. Now ask: What are they aware with? Awareness.
Ask: Can you find a boundary to awareness? Where does 'your' awareness end and 'their' awareness begin?
Notice that awareness has no boundaries. The belief in separate awarenesses is just a thought.
Recognize: there is only one awareness, appearing from different perspectives. We share our being.
Rest in this recognition. Notice how the sense of separation dissolves in the recognition of shared being.

sequences.title: Welcoming All Experience
sequences.description: Learning to allow experience without resistance

steps.instruction: Notice an uncomfortable feeling or difficult thought. Don't try to change it.
Ask: What is aware of this discomfort? Notice that awareness itself is not uncomfortable.
Notice any resistance to the experience. Recognize resistance itself as an object appearing in awareness.
Allow the experience to be exactly as it is. Don't push it away, don't pull it close. Simply let it be.
Notice that when resistance ceases, even difficult experience is welcomed in awareness. This is acceptance.
Rest as awareness, the allowing space in which all experience is embraced.
